questions.text: In urea cycle disorder, which of the following substance can be used to reduce the levels of ammonia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phenylbutyrate In all urea cycle disorders there is accumulation of NH 3 (hyperammonemia) which is very toxic and has to be removed. Using scavenging agents:- One of the treatments of urea cycle disorder is the use of NH 3 scavenging agents. These are Phenylbutyrate and Sodium benzoate. Phenyl butyrate reacts with glutamine to get converted into phenyl acetyl glutamine which can be excreted. Other method to treat urea cycle disorder is Arginine supplementation (1st line treatment) : Arginine is an essential amino acid. It provides ornithine (required in 2nd step of urea cycle) which is an activator of NAGS. But it is contraindicated in Arginase deficiency

questions.text: The given below clinical features occurs due to deficiency of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tryptophan Characterized by: 4 Ds of Pellagra Vitamin B 3 Deficiency: Pellagra Additional Edge: 60 mg tryptophan gets converted to 1 mg Niacin. Niacin is formed from tryptophan amino acid. So, tryptophan deficiency can also lead to Casal’s necklace. This is Casal’s necklace shown in picture, which occurs in Vitamin B3/ Niacin deficiency . Dermatitis (Photosensitive Dermatitis) Diarrhoea Dementia Death

questions.text: Which of the following binds mRNA with ribosome in eukaryotes?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

7-methylguanosine cap In eukaryotic cells, ribosomes recognize most eukaryotic mRNAs by binding to the 7-methylguanosine cap at their 5´ terminus. Shine Dalgarno sequence (SD sequence) is present at -10 position on mRNA, only in prokaryotes and is rich in purines. In smaller subunit of ribosome, 16 s rRNA is present. SD sequence is complementary to 16 s rRNA, and their binding helps in binding of mRNA with ribosome during initiation of translation in prokaryotes.

questions.text: Which of the following glycoprotein has both lubricant and protective action:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mucin Mucins are a family of high molecular weight and heavily glycosylated proteins. These large glycoproteins are secreted in mucus, the viscous fluid that protects and lubricates the epithelium of the gastrointestinal, genitourinary, and respiratory tracts. However, some mucins may be membrane associated and not secreted. Additional Edge Glycoproteins are proteins that contain oligosaccharide chains (glycans) covalently attached to their polypeptide backbones. O-linked glycoproteins and N-linked glycoproteins are major classes of glycoproteins. Linked glycoprotein : These are glycoproteins where O- glycosylation occurs at serine or threonine residues . Serine is more common. N- linked glycoproteins : These are glycoproteins where N- glycosidic linkage takes place between amide nitrogen of Asparagine.

questions.text: All of the following are correct about Proteoglycans except:

options.label: B
options.text: Made of protein and sugar MPS

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Doesn’t hold water Chondroitin sulfate is a glycosaminoglycan -> option 1 is true Proteoglycan = core protein (Amino acid) + Glycosaminoglycan (sugar) -> option 3 is true Sulfate and acetyl groups confer negative charge to the amino acids -> option 4 is true As they are negatively charged, they can hold large amount of water, not less -> option 2 is wrong.

questions.text: Restriction endonuclease will act on which of the following:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

AAGCTT Restriction endonuclease (also known as Molecular Scissor) cuts palindromic sequences. Palindromic sequence is that when sequence is same on both the strands of DNA. A palindromic sequence is a sequence on ds-DNA that is the same when read from 5' to 3' on one strand and 5' to 3' on the other, complementary strand. An example of a palindromic sequence is 5'-GGATCC-3', which has a complementary strand, 3'-CCTAGG-5’. Option A is a palindrome i.e. 5’ AAGCTT 3’ and other complementary strand is 3’ TTCGAA 5’.

questions.text: Which replacement of amino acid does not alter its normal function?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glutamine replaced by asparagine Glutamine and asparagine are uncharged polar amino acids. Both have amide group. So exchange of these amino acids in a protein will not change the charge of the protein. Arginine is basic amino acid, so it is positively charged. Glutamate is acidic amino acid, so it is negatively charged. Alanine is non-polar

questions.text: In CRISPR-Cas 9 system, which repair mechanism is used for genome editing?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Non homologous end repair CRISPR-Cas-9 endonuclease system introduces double stranded breaks in DNA at the specific target site. Now cell tries to repair this double stranded break by two mechanism: Non-homologous end repair or Homologous repair Nonhomologous repair mechanism is always a possibility as it does not require homologous DNA. So, it is the major repair mechanism during CRISPR-Cas system. The homologous repair will only work if the DNA homologous to the cut DNA is present but is not always present.

questions.text: Assertion: Most common hematological disorder in chronic lead poisoning is eosinophilia. Reason: Chronic lead poisoning inhibits the enzyme ALA dehydratase.

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently a false/incorrect statement

options.label: D
options.text: Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently true/correct statement

questions.correct_answer: D. Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently true/correct statement
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently true/correct statement Lead poisoning most commonly cause acquired porphyria Lead inhibits two enzymes: ALA dehydratase Ferrochelatase

questions.text: In low insulin: glucagon ratio. What is correct?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increase activity of HSL Insulin is released in Fed state. So low insulin means Fasting state or catabolic state. Insulin activates all anabolic pathways enzymes i.e. HMP, Glycogenesis, FA synthesis, Cholesterol synthesis, TG synthesis, Lipoprotein Lipase enzyme. EXCEPTION: Insulin activates two catabolic pathway enzymes i.e. Glycolysis & Link reaction. Glucagon activates all catabolic pathways enzymes i.e. Glycogenolysis, beta-oxidation of fatty acids, Gluconeogenesis, Ketone body synthesis, Ketone body utilization and Hormone sensitive lipase.

questions.text: The biochemical basis of scurvy is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Impaired collagen synthesis Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C) is necessary for the post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues. Hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine are important for the formation of cross links in the collagen , which gives the tensile strength to the fibers. This process is necessary for the normal production of supporting tissues such as osteoid, collagen and intercellular cement substance of capillaries . Vitamin C deficiency causes Scurvy- with features such as Gum becomes painful, swollen, spongy and loosening of teeth. Delayed Wound healing.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option B. Increased keratinization of epithelium: Occur in Vitamin A deficiency Option C. Inhibition of clotting factors: Occur in Vitamin K deficiency Option D. Low calcium: associated with Vitamin D deficiency
